Detailed Description

Finds a sum-of-exponentials fit to a monotonic, anitsymmetric function.

The function is sampled at a set of points. One half of the points are provided on construction, these are reflected about the point one half step above the last point.

Author:
Daniel Tang

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

AntisymmetricExpFit::AntisymmetricExpFit ( const std::vector< double > &  y,
bool  p = true 
)

Constructs an instance of AsymmetricExpFit, forms the Hankel matrix and solves for the eigenvectors.

Parameters:
y Half of the data we wish to find an antisymmetric fit of. The point of antisymmetry lies at y.size()-0.5. y.size() should be even.
p if true, the provable method of solving is used, otherwise the alternative method is used. See accompanying paper for further details.

Member Function Documentation

void AntisymmetricExpFit::fit ( double  max_error  ) 

Fits an exponential sum to the data in the Hankel matrix, H, whose error is bounded by max_error

void AntisymmetricExpFit::fit ( int  n  ) 

Fits an exponential sum with 'n' terms to the data in the Hankel matrix, H.

bool  p = true 
)

Used to define the data points we wish to fit the approximant to (if different from that sent to the constructor).

Parameters:
y Half of the data to fit. The point of antisymmetry lies at y.size()-0.5. y.size() should be even
p if true, the provable method of solving is used, otherwise the alternative method is used. See accompanying paper for further details.

void AntisymmetricExpFit::fit_exponents ( int  c  ) 

Find zeroes of the polynomial , where is the eigenvector, and put any zeroes that lie in the interval [0:1] into k.

Parameters:
c The identifier of the eigenvector to find zeroes of.

Solevs the Vandermonde system to find the least squares fit of the amplitudes for a given k.
